257b0ac4b630260a9301900d925c83c4a13ad6b3:
"Peter and Wendy" by J.M. Barrie follows the adventures of Wendy Darling and her brothers John and Michael as they travel to Neverland with Peter Pan, the boy who never grows up. In Neverland, they encounter pirates, mermaids, magical creatures, and the lost boys. Wendy becomes a mother-figure to Peter and the lost boys, and together they build a home underground and become friends with the redskins. They prepare for and successfully ward off a big pirate attack, led by Captain Hook, whom Peter ultimately kills.

Throughout the story, the struggles of motherhood and eternal youth of childhood are highlighted. After their adventures, Peter returns Wendy and the lost boys home, where their parents decide to adopt the lost boys. Peter, however, chooses not to stay and continues his life in Neverland. As Wendy grows older, she recounts her adventures to her daughter Jane, who eventually meets Peter and flies with him to Neverland. The story suggests that Peter will continue to visit and take future generations of children to Neverland as long as they remain innocent, symbolizing the cycle of growing up and moving on.
298a037a20c9570a7d610d7a642c63725f4ce3f4:
[[[The book begins with the narrator, who is also the protagonist, reflecting on advice his father gave him about not being too critical of others, as not everyone has had the same advantages. The narrator explains that he tends to reserve judgment and be open to learning about people's unique experiences. He recalls being accused of being a politician in college because he frequently became privy to people's personal confessions. Though he prides himself on his tolerance, he admits to having a limit and shares his disdain for a man named Gatsby. Despite this, he acknowledges Gatsby's charismatic personality and extraordinary gift for hope. The narrator ends by stating that something about the tragedy of Gatsby's life temporarily closed off his interest in the sorrows and joys of others.

The narrator then introduces his own background, mentioning his family's prominence and his familial ties to the Dukes of Buccleuch. He explains that his great-uncle established their family's reputation and wealth by starting a successful hardware business. The narrator attended Yale University and fought in World War I. After the war, he moved to the East, wanting to experience the excitement of the bond business. He rented a house in a unique community on an island near New York called West Egg and describes his surroundings and the wealth of his neighbors.

The story transitions to the narrator's visit to his second cousin once removed, Daisy Buchanan, and her husband Tom Buchanan, whom the narrator knew from college. Daisy married Tom, who was a successful football player in college and comes from a wealthy family. They had recently moved to the East from Chicago after spending a year in France. The narrator describes their extravagant mansion and the grandeur of their surroundings. He arrives at their house and is greeted by Tom, who has changed since their college days. The narrator notices Tom's physical dominance and arrogance. The three spend time together, and the narrator is introduced to another woman named Jordan Baker. He is instantly charmed by Daisy's charm and Jordan's allure. The chapter ends with Miss Baker appearing momentarily shaken by something.]]]
6df578fcb8a876f0d2ce310dc233c32686c4e401: [[[In this passage, Nick is at a gathering with his cousin Daisy, her husband Tom Buchanan, and their friend Jordan Baker. Daisy asks him about his recent trip to Chicago and if people there miss her. They discuss Daisy's three-year-old daughter, whom Nick has never seen, and Tom interrupts their conversation. Tom, who is restless, asks Nick about his work as a bond man and makes a dismissive comment about his company. Daisy's friend, Miss Baker, suddenly speaks up and agrees with Tom's statement. The conversation then shifts to a discussion about civilization and race, where Tom expresses his pessimistic views. Daisy interrupts the conversation and changes the topic, talking about a butler's nose and their romantic surroundings. Miss Baker tries to eavesdrop on a conversation happening inside, and later reveals that Tom is involved with another woman in New York. The atmosphere becomes tense, with the horses they were planning to ride being forgotten. Tom and Miss Baker go to the library, while Daisy takes Nick to the porch and discusses her cynical outlook on life. She tells him about the birth of her daughter and her hope that she will be a "beautiful little fool." However, Nick senses the insincerity behind her words. The passage ends with Tom and Miss Baker sitting together, with her reading to him while the room is filled with a warm glow.]]]
079d7458adc16f09183c58a32b077d223d922bc4: [[[When Nick arrives at the Buchanan's house, he meets Jordan Baker, a famous golfer. Daisy and Tom discuss Jordan's upcoming golf tournament, and Daisy comes up with the idea of arranging a marriage between Nick and Jordan. Tom disapproves of Jordan's independent lifestyle and believes that she should have more familial guidance. As Nick leaves, Daisy questions him about rumors of his engagement, to which he denies. He reflects on the evening as he drives home to West Egg, where he sees a figure resembling Gatsby standing outside his mansion. The next day, Nick and Tom visit the "valley of ashes," a desolate area filled with ash, and later meet Tom's mistress, Myrtle Wilson, at a garage. Tom makes plans to meet Myrtle in New York, and they all head to the city together. Myrtle buys a dog from a street vendor, and Tom insists on accompanying her to her apartment, leaving Nick behind.]]]
0a645d32e4ddfd79b8749855d8b42a8da74e0550: [[[After returning to the city, the narrator and Mrs. Wilson go up to her apartment, where they are joined by the McKees, a couple from the flat below. The small apartment is filled with oversized furniture and tacky decorations. Mrs. Wilson attends to her dog while Mrs. McKee and Mr. McKee discuss his photography. Mrs. Wilson's personality becomes more affected and grandiose, and she shares stories about her experiences with various people. The conversation then turns to the topic of Tom and Myrtle's unhappy marriages. Catherine, Myrtle's sister, shares that Myrtle's Catholicism prevents her from divorcing her husband, but they plan on moving to the West together in the future. The gathering becomes increasingly intoxicated, and tensions rise when the topic of Daisy is brought up. Eventually, people start leaving and the atmosphere becomes chaotic, with arguments breaking out. The chapter ends late at night with Mr. McKee asleep and the little dog groaning.]]]
96a4d7680ca9aab905a77232ec02580b8e1affbc:
[[[In this chunk, the scene shifts to Tom Buchanan breaking Myrtle Wilson's nose during an argument. There is chaos as women scold and console Myrtle, and Mr. McKee stands bewildered before leaving. The narrator, Nick Carraway, follows Mr. McKee and agrees to have lunch with him. The scene transitions to Nick standing beside Gatsby's bed as he flips through a portfolio filled with pictures and clippings. The chunk ends with Nick waiting at the train station. 

The next chunk describes the extravagant parties at Gatsby's house. The parties are filled with music, guests, and lavish decorations. The guests come and go, engaging in various activities such as diving, sunbathing, and riding aquaplanes. Gatsby's servants work tirelessly to prepare for these parties, and crates of oranges and lemons are shipped in every week. Caterers set up grand buffets, and a full orchestra provides music for the guests. The parties are filled with laughter, conversation, and mingling between people who may not even know each other's names. The chunk ends with the start of one of Gatsby's parties, where the narrator realizes that he is one of the few invited guests. People typically attend Gatsby's parties without formal invitations. The narrator recounts how he received a personal invitation from Gatsby, and he describes his first impressions of the party and the people attending it. He also overhears rumors about Gatsby, including speculation about him being a German spy or having killed someone. The chunk concludes with the narrator leaving the party and joining Jordan Baker, who takes him to meet Gatsby. They first encounter a drunken man in Gatsby's library, who shows them a book from the library before they continue exploring the party. The chunk ends with dancing and merriment at the party.]]]
f90775766a27aae8f79fb77be4e2d6fb5e836ea0: [[[At the party, the protagonist is sitting with Jordan Baker and another man. The man recognizes the protagonist from their time serving in the military together. The man invites the protagonist to go boating the next morning. Suddenly, the man reveals that he is Gatsby, the host of the party. Surprised, the protagonist is fascinated by Gatsby's smile, which conveys understanding and reassurance. Gatsby is called away by a butler, and the protagonist learns from Jordan that Gatsby claims to be an Oxford man, but she doubts it. The atmosphere at the party becomes chaotic, with fights breaking out among the guests. Jordan leaves to speak with Gatsby privately, and the protagonist decides to join the remaining guests. As he leaves, he witnesses a car accident outside Gatsby's house. The car's wheel has come off, and a man stumbles out of the wreck asking for a gas station. It becomes clear that the wheel was never attached properly in the first place.]]]
b9ba3f85dbfd5ddbc27695862044357e12e858b0: [[[In this passage, the narrator reflects on his daily routine and describes his experiences in New York City. He works in the morning and lunches with colleagues. After work, he studies investments and securities at the library and then takes leisurely walks through the city, observing the bustling nightlife. He also mentions his brief affair with a woman from Jersey City and his growing attraction to a golfer named Jordan Baker. The narrator reveals that he is writing letters to someone back home and mentions his belief in his own honesty. The passage then transitions to a description of the people who attended Gatsby's parties, listing their names and backgrounds. Finally, the narrator recounts a conversation with Gatsby, where Gatsby opens up about his past and explains that he inherited wealth after his family died. The narrator expresses doubt about Gatsby's story, but also wonders if there is something sinister about him.]]]
cc4b886bb71ec486f298d2601c1db8e95ce6ae15: [[[The narrator meets Gatsby for lunch in a restaurant. Gatsby introduces the narrator to his friend, Mr. Wolfshiem, a small, flat-nosed Jew. Mr. Wolfshiem tells a story about a man named Rosy Rosenthal being shot outside a restaurant. Gatsby abruptly leaves the table, and Mr. Wolfshiem talks to the narrator about Gatsby's character and background. Gatsby returns to the table, and the conversation shifts to the narrator's lunch with Miss Baker later that day. Gatsby asks the narrator to listen to Miss Baker's conversation regarding a certain matter. After Mr. Wolfshiem leaves, Gatsby reveals to the narrator that he is careful about women and would never pursue a friend's wife. Later, the narrator pays the bill and sees Tom Buchanan, who confronts the narrator for not calling Daisy. Gatsby is no longer at the table.]]]
94e28482306e3aae6627f12387417cafe23777e9: [[[In this chunk of the book, Jordan Baker tells the narrator about her encounter with Daisy Fay and her first meeting with Jay Gatsby. It is revealed that Daisy was once popular and had many suitors, but rumors circulated about her relationship with a soldier. Eventually, she married Tom Buchanan. On the day of her wedding, Daisy got very drunk and contemplated calling off the wedding. However, she went through with it, and they had a child together. Years later, Daisy hears the name Gatsby for the first time and becomes curious about him. Jordan reveals that Gatsby wants the narrator to invite Daisy to his house so that they can see each other again, as Gatsby has bought his house specifically for this purpose. The chunk ends with the narrator agreeing to invite Daisy to tea.]]]
89d72af5332059d1d1785da17eabd76c4adda691: [[[Gatsby asks the narrator to cut his grass, but the narrator remembers he forgot to tell his worker to come back. He goes to search for her in the village and buys some items. Gatsby sends a greenhouse with flowers. Gatsby arrives at the narrator's house looking pale and sleep-deprived. They discuss the weather and preparations for tea. Gatsby becomes restless and decides to go home because he thinks nobody will come. Just as he's about to leave, Daisy, Gatsby's love interest, pulls up in a car. They both go inside and talk while the narrator waits outside. Gatsby looks distressed, but Daisy appears happy. The narrator leaves them alone and goes outside. After some time, Gatsby invites Daisy to see his house, and they all go together. Gatsby shows off his luxurious home to Daisy, and she is impressed. They proceed to explore the rest of the house, encountering various rooms along the way. Gatsby becomes increasingly infatuated with Daisy's presence. Finally, they sit down in Gatsby's bedroom and share a moment of laughter and intimacy.]]]
bb24048c287bcf299d93e4a86475b520c939c91b: [[[In this chunk, Gatsby showcases his collection of shirts to Daisy and her friend. Daisy becomes emotional and begins crying because she has never seen such beautiful shirts before. Later, Gatsby shows Daisy a photograph of his deceased best friend, Mr. Dan Cody, and another picture of himself when he was younger. Daisy expresses her admiration for Gatsby's pompadour hairstyle and yacht. Gatsby then shows Daisy newspaper clippings about her and they stand side by side examining them. They are interrupted by a phone call, but Daisy calls Gatsby to the window to show him a beautiful pink and golden sunset. Gatsby suggests they have Klipspringer play the piano for them, and he brings in a young man named Ewing Klipspringer. They all gather in the music room, where Gatsby turns on the lights and Klipspringer plays the piano. The chapter ends with the narrator leaving Gatsby's house in the rain, leaving Gatsby and Daisy alone. In the subsequent chunk, a reporter arrives at the house and questions Gatsby about his background, prompting Gatsby to reflect on his past and his transformation from James Gatz to Jay Gatsby. Gatsby shares the story of how he met Dan Cody, a wealthy man whom he worked for and inherited money from. Cody introduced Gatsby to a life of luxury and excess, but Gatsby ultimately did not receive the entirety of his inheritance due to legal issues. The chunk concludes with the narrator stating that Gatsby divulged this information to him later on, in an attempt to dispel rumors and misconceptions about his past.]]]
60f6939ddf9a73bfa48425c5ff9c0d992ab50309: [[[Gatsby is affected by Tom's presence and feels uneasy until he can offer them something. Mr. Sloane declines any drinks, but the conversation continues. Gatsby tries to engage Tom, mentioning that they had met before, but Tom does not remember. Gatsby mentions knowing Daisy, which catches Tom's attention. They discuss their proximity and Gatsby invites them to stay for supper, but they decline and leave. Later, Tom and Daisy attend one of Gatsby's parties, but Daisy is not fully enjoying herself. Daisy comments on the interesting people at the party, while Tom remains skeptical. Daisy and Gatsby dance and then sit on the steps while Tom joins other people for dinner. Daisy sings and Tom questions Gatsby's background. Daisy mentions that Gatsby owns drugstores and Tom decides to learn more about him. Before leaving, Daisy expresses a sense of longing and curiosity about what may unfold during the night.]]]
0206760d5200ae9fc1035a924e6f58634f0b92bb: [[[On a cool night with a hint of mystery in the air, Gatsby gazes at the lights in the houses and feels a sense of anticipation. He sees the blocks of the sidewalks as a ladder leading to a secret place above the trees, where he can find wonder and excitement. He knows that when he kisses Daisy, his mind will never be the same. Meanwhile, Nick is reminded of a distant memory and struggles to recall it. The next day, Gatsby's house experiences a power outage, signaling the end of his extravagant lifestyle. Nick goes to check on Gatsby, only to be met with suspicion from the new butler. It is revealed that Gatsby has replaced his servants with people associated with Meyer Wolfsheim. Gatsby invites Nick to lunch at Daisy's house, and when Nick agrees, Gatsby mentions that Daisy often visits him in the afternoons. The scene shifts to the next day, which is scorching hot. The intense heat affects everyone's mood as they try to find relief. Daisy suggests they all go to town, and Tom reluctantly agrees. Gatsby, Tom, and Nick engage in a tense conversation, and Daisy's voice is described as being "full of money." Ultimately, Gatsby agrees to let Tom drive his car while he takes Tom's coupe. They all set off for town.]]]
983e74e551d09ae377e66cb4a957b73c995ce15b: [[[Gatsby offers to take Daisy in his car, but she insists on following in a separate car with Jordan and Nick. They drive off, leaving Tom behind. Tom questions Jordan and Nick about their knowledge of Gatsby, revealing that he had been investigating Gatsby's past. Tom is surprised to learn that Gatsby is rumored to be an Oxford man, when in fact he's from Oxford, New Mexico. Tom justifies his investigation as a result of his suspicions about Gatsby's character. They stop at a garage where Wilson, the proprietor, looks ill and in need of money. Tom offers to sell his car to Wilson, mentioning that he wants to get away from the area. Wilson's wife, Myrtle, watches from a nearby window with a jealous expression. They continue the drive to the Plaza Hotel, where tensions rise and an argument ensues. Daisy suggests renting multiple rooms, which escalates into getting a suite, and finally into having mint juleps. Daisy's suggestion to relax and enjoy the heat disquiets Tom. They eventually end up in a room with a view of the wedding ceremony downstairs. The heat intensifies, and Tom questions Gatsby about his past, specifically his time at Oxford. Gatsby claims to have briefly attended Oxford after the war as part of a program offered to officers. Tom accuses Gatsby of causing trouble and tries to defend the sanctity of family and racial purity. The argument becomes more heated, but Daisy begs for peace. Gatsby tries to interject with something important, but Daisy interrupts him, pleading for everyone to calm down.]]]
a930d201c35b2986f120cb699fa7928d60f44845: [[[Tom, Gatsby, Daisy, and Jordan are having a tense conversation about their relationships. Gatsby reveals that Daisy had never loved Tom and only married him because Gatsby was poor. Tom denies this and claims that Daisy loves him. Daisy hesitates but eventually admits that she never loved Tom. Gatsby insists that Daisy leave Tom, but Tom mocks him and accuses him of being a bootlegger. Gatsby tries to defend himself, but Daisy ends up sobbing and confessing that she loved both Tom and Gatsby at different times. Tom asserts that Daisy will never leave him, and Gatsby becomes panicked. They argue further until Daisy asks to leave. Gatsby insists on speaking to Daisy alone, but she refuses. Tom reveals that he knows about Gatsby's illegal activities and threatens to expose him. They all leave, and on the way home, Tom learns about Myrtle's death in a car accident. The chapter ends with Wilson, Myrtle's husband, in distress at the sight of her body.]]]
6842c174de0a40d489f0d76148a56424d2595696:
[[[Wilson is in a state of shock after his wife Myrtle's death. He repeats the same phrase over and over while Tom and a policeman try to speak to him. Tom tells the police officer that Myrtle was instantly killed when a yellow car struck her as she ran out into the road. Tom clarifies that the yellow car he was driving earlier in the day was not his, and he hasn't seen it since. Wilson becomes agitated and insists that he knows what kind of car hit his wife. Tom tries to calm him down and reassures him that he just arrived from New York and wasn't involved in the accident. Tom carries Wilson into the office and asks someone to sit with him while he goes outside. Tom and Nick leave the scene, and as they drive away, Tom is visibly upset and calls the driver of the yellow car a coward for not stopping. 

Later that night, Tom takes Nick to the Buchanans' house. Tom tells Nick to wait outside while he goes inside to deal with the situation. Tom informs Nick that they can't do anything at the moment and that he will call a taxi for him to go home. Jordan tries to convince Nick to come inside, but he declines and waits outside. Jordan eventually goes inside as well. Feeling sick, Nick decides to leave and orders a taxi. As he walks away, he encounters Gatsby, who asks if there has been any news. Nick assures him that everything is quiet and advises him to go home and get some rest. Gatsby refuses and plans to stay outside Daisy's window to make sure she is safe. Satisfied with Gatsby's determination, Nick leaves him and walks away. Nick spends the night unable to sleep, tormented by dreams and the groaning sound of a foghorn. At dawn, he sees a taxi arriving at Gatsby's house. He finds Gatsby leaning against a table in the hall, looking dejected. Gatsby tells Nick that nothing happened and that Daisy turned off the light at around four in the morning. They explore the empty and dusty house, smoking cigarettes and discussing Gatsby's past with Dan Cody. Despite Nick's suggestion that Gatsby should leave town, Gatsby is determined to stay until he knows what Daisy will do. Finally, Gatsby opens up to Nick about his relationship with Daisy, emphasizing her allure and how she was the first truly nice girl he had known. He describes the air of mystery and excitement that surrounded Daisy's luxurious home and the many men who had loved her. Gatsby acknowledges that his present situation as Jay Gatsby is precarious because his wealth and status could disappear at any moment.]]]
cafcf3a335f2bf47721dce7d32386229e9aa2e08:
[[[Gatsby takes whatever he can get, even if it means being unscrupulous. He ends up taking Daisy one night, realizing that he doesn't have the right to touch her but still feeling a deep connection to her. Daisy believes that Gatsby is from a similar background as her and can take care of her, but in reality, he has no such capabilities. Despite this, Gatsby becomes committed to pursuing a relationship with Daisy.

They meet again a few days later, where Gatsby is the one who is breathless and betrayed. Daisy's wealth and luxurious lifestyle make Gatsby feel insignificant and leave him with nothing. He still loves her deeply and feels married to her. 

Gatsby reflects on how he unexpectedly fell in love with Daisy and how he didn't care about achieving his ambitions anymore. He wanted to share his plans with her instead. They have a beautiful moment together before he leaves for the war.

During the war, Gatsby excels and achieves a high rank. After the war, he tries desperately to return home and be with Daisy, but complications arise, and he ends up going to Oxford instead. Daisy feels pressured by the outside world and wants to be reassured that she's making the right choices.

Daisy immerses herself in her artificial world of wealth and snobbery, going on countless dates with several men. She feels the need for her life to have direction and wants a force, whether it's love, money, or practicality, to shape her life.

Tom Buchanan arrives on the scene and provides the force she's been looking for. He is flattered by Daisy's attention, and their relationship gives her some relief. Gatsby receives a letter from Daisy, expressing her unhappiness and longing for him to be with her. Gatsby feels worried and leaves for Louisville, where he spent time with Daisy before. He feels melancholy about the city but leaves, believing he didn't search hard enough for her.

Back in Long Island, Gatsby reflects on his love for Daisy and realizes that it was a personal matter. The narrator recalls a moment when Gatsby's dream was concealed while waving goodbye to those who suspected his corruption. The narrator thanks Gatsby for his hospitality.

The narrator returns to the city and receives a call from Jordan Baker, who plans to meet him but is upset with him. He doesn't want to see her anyway and hangs up. The narrator tries calling Gatsby but can't get through. Feeling uneasy, he circles the time of his train departure on his timetable.

The next morning, the narrator recalls passing the ash-heaps on the train, intentionally avoiding looking at them. He then goes back to when he left the garage the night before. There was chaos as they tried to locate Myrtle's sister and bring her to the morgue. Eventually, George Wilson started speaking incoherently about the yellow car and his wife's injuries. Michaelis tries to distract him and asks about his marriage and children. Michaelis, feeling uncomfortable, moves around the office while George continues to mourn and express his pain.]]]
3fef5fa3b32c2e1452075f15f8e24d3b81c5450d: [[[George Wilson, distraught over his wife Myrtle's death, expresses his belief that she was murdered. He reveals that she had a dog leash which he found suspicious. Michaelis, a friend of Wilson's, tries to offer alternate explanations, but Wilson is convinced that the man in the yellow car is responsible. Wilson begins to search for the owner of the car, eventually making his way to Gatsby's house. The chapter then shifts to Gatsby's perspective, as he prepares for his usual morning swim. He tells his staff not to take the car out, which is strange because it needs repair. Gatsby heads to the pool with an air mattress, while the phone at his house remains unanswered. As a crowd gathers outside his house, rumors and false reports about the incident spread. Nick, feeling responsible for Gatsby, tries to find someone to help him and calls both Daisy and Gatsby's business associate, Meyer Wolfshiem. However, Daisy and Tom have left town and Wolfshiem refuses to get involved. Nick feels a sense of solidarity with Gatsby against the judgment of others. Eventually, Gatsby's father arrives, and Nick takes care of him while he waits for the funeral to be postponed.]]]
b5e8584300801f0cb8290938db1d1eea197f4295: [[[A man arrives at Gatsby's house and reveals that he saw the news of Gatsby's death in a newspaper. The man appears distraught and his eyes constantly move around the room. He mentions that Gatsby was killed by a madman. The narrator offers him some coffee, but the man refuses. The man then asks about Gatsby's whereabouts. The narrator takes him to see Gatsby's body. Meanwhile, boys outside the house reluctantly leave when they learn of the man's arrival. After a while, Gatsby's father, Mr. Gatz, comes out of the room and seems proud of the grandeur of the house. The narrator assists Mr. Gatz to a bedroom and informs him that arrangements for the funeral have been postponed until Mr. Gatz arrives. Mr. Gatz mentions that Gatsby had a bright future ahead and had a lot of potential. The next day, the narrator receives a call from a person named Klipspringer, who sounds relieved to hear the narrator's voice. They discuss Gatsby's funeral, and Klipspringer mentions a picnic he is expected to attend. The narrator hangs up after suspecting Klipspringer's insincerity. Later, the narrator tries to reach Meyer Wolfshiem, a business associate of Gatsby's, and goes to his office but finds him absent. The narrator then goes to visit Gatsby's father, who proudly shows him a picture of Gatsby and talks about his son's success. He also shows the narrator an old book owned by Gatsby and reads the schedule Gatsby had written in it as a young boy. The day of the funeral arrives, but no one except Gatsby's father and the narrator show up. They proceed to the cemetery, where they encounter a man with owl-eyed glasses who had previously seen Gatsby's books in the library. He remarks on the lack of visitors at the funeral. The chapter ends with the narrator reminiscing about his past experiences of returning home for the holidays.]]]
602ced3f18d04cd001de9844aeeecb78b187702a:
[[[The narrator reflects on the experience of driving through the snow-filled countryside and feeling a deep sense of connection to his Middle West roots. He explains how his identity is shaped by memories of returning trains, street lamps, and the beauty of winter in his hometown. He also acknowledges that he and the other characters in the story are Westerners who struggle to adapt to the fast-paced and distorted world of the East.

In another passage, the narrator recounts a confrontation with Tom Buchanan, in which he asks about Tom's conversation with Wilson on the day of Myrtle's death. Tom admits to telling Wilson the truth about who owned the car but justifies it by saying that Myrtle's death was her own fault for running in front of the car. The narrator realizes that Tom and Daisy are careless people who cause destruction and expect others to clean up after them.

Later, the narrator contemplates Gatsby's empty house and the memories of his extravagant parties. He erases an obscene word written on the steps and reflects on the beauty of the land before Gatsby's mansion was built. He recalls Gatsby's relentless pursuit of his dream, symbolized by the green light at the end of Daisy's dock. He realizes that Gatsby's dream was already behind him, and despite the elusiveness of the future, he believes in the continuous pursuit of dreams. The story ends with the imagery of boats against the current, representing the perpetual struggle against the past.]]]
135b85be59d69ccbcd3459e6787526482c3e4522: [[[The chunk begins with Gatsby offering to take Daisy in his car, but she insists on following in a separate car with Jordan and Nick. They drive off, leaving Tom behind. Tom questions Jordan and Nick about their knowledge of Gatsby, revealing that he had been investigating Gatsby's past. Tom is surprised to learn that Gatsby is rumored to be an Oxford man, when in fact he's from Oxford, New Mexico. Tom justifies his investigation as a result of his suspicions about Gatsby's character. They stop at a garage where Wilson, the proprietor, looks ill and in need of money. Tom offers to sell his car to Wilson, mentioning that he wants to get away from the area. Wilson's wife, Myrtle, watches from a nearby window with a jealous expression. They continue the drive to the Plaza Hotel, where tensions rise and an argument ensues. Daisy suggests renting multiple rooms, which escalates into getting a suite, and finally into having mint juleps. Daisy's suggestion to relax and enjoy the heat disquiets Tom.]]]
2ae3dc0cdf6ea2668764d066e0f67b9bb480e6db: [[[In this chunk, the narrative shifts to the aftermath of Myrtle's death. Wilson, in a state of shock, insists that his wife was murdered and sets out to find the owner of the yellow car. Meanwhile, Gatsby goes about his usual routine while rumors circulate about his involvement in the incident. Nick tries to find help for Gatsby but is unsuccessful. Gatsby's father arrives, and Nick takes care of him until the funeral can be postponed. Later, a man arrives at Gatsby's house and reveals that he saw news of Gatsby's death in a newspaper. The man appears distraught and asks about Gatsby's whereabouts. The narrator takes him to see Gatsby's body, and eventually, Gatsby's father, Mr. Gatz, comes out and expresses pride in his son's achievements. The narrator receives a call from Klipspringer, who seems insincere, and tries to reach Meyer Wolfshiem but finds him absent. He then visits Gatsby's father, who shows him a picture and an old book that belonged to Gatsby. On the day of the funeral, only Gatsby's father and the narrator show up. They proceed to the cemetery, where they encounter a man with owl-eyed glasses who remarks on the lack of visitors. The chapter ends with the narrator reflecting on his Middle West roots and the struggle to adapt to the East. He also contemplates Gatsby's empty house and the pursuit of dreams against the perpetual struggle of the past.]]]
